page.title: 08 ST. MARY'S CHURCH
page.content: Between 1170-1180 during the reign of Henry II a stone church was built.Today it has the oldest, the tallest and most perfect timber spire in the country. The nave is Norman, having rounded arches and windows and pillars, which are short and thick. On the capitals the decoration is scalloped. There is also a Norman font at the west end of the north aisle. Early in the 13th century, during King John's reign the tower was added. At that time it was separate from the church and stood on four corner piers, the arches being open. It is in the Early English style and the remains of a mass-dial can be seen scratched on the south-east pier. A monk's cell was added at the north-east end for the priest and passing pilgrims. It has two storeys.
